docs.lead_paragraph: Judging by what has happened since reunification in 1990, Germany is likely to be more preoccupied with itself over the next five years than intent on exercising the new economic and political might that made its European neighbors so uneasy five years ago. Chancellor Helmut Kohl rammed unification through the NATO alliance and the European Community in 1989 and 1990, brushing aside fears that Europe would be dominated by a German colossus of 80 million people.

headline.main: Germans, 5 Years Later: Bitter and Still Divided

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Express Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations rose 16 percent as consumer spending increased and profits from the company's insurance and mutual fund subsidiary advanced. The travel and finance company said income from continuing operations increased to $335 million, or 65 cents a share, from $291 million, or 57 cents, a year earlier.

docs.lead_paragraph: The ovens of industry are burning with gusto in this old prairie city's east end, where factories abut dormant black cornfields and the asphalt skirts of auto body shops and bowling alleys. Day and night, the A. E. Staley corn milling plant belches plumes of smoke that dust the downtown with a scent as sweet and thick as a bakery's. A few blocks up 22d Street from Staley, the two-story brick plant of the world's No. 1 tire and rubber company, the Bridgestone Corporation of Tokyo, is operating, too, and so, a few blocks farther up 22d, is the still bigger plant of the world's No. 1 producer of earth-moving equipment, Caterpillar Inc. of Peoria.

headline.main: Illinois Town a 'Testing Field' in Labor Relations

docs.lead_paragraph: As if the rumbling earth had not created enough misery here, the skies opened up today and poured down more of it, with heavy rains in Kobe threatening to touch off landslides and topple earthquake-weakened buildings. The rain complicated the search for nearly 200 people still listed as missing after the deadliest earthquake in Japan in more than 70 years. The death toll approached 5,000 tonight and seems likely to exceed that number later this week.

headline.main: Rain Adds to Misery of Quake Survivors

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH health maintenance organizations and other managed-care groups taking over an ever larger share of the health care market, thousands of physicians across the state have signed up for two new doctor-owned H.M.O.'s. And largely in response to physicians' complaints, the State Department of Health has undertaken a major revision of the regulations governing H.M.O.'s. Under the managed-care system, some insurance companies and other owners of H.M.O.'s form separate corporations and subsidiaries to monitor the performance of participating physicians and other providers of health care. Others contract for the service with independent managed-care companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: BARELY two months into his job, Thomas A. Bartlett, the new Chancellor of the State University of New York, visited Purchase College recently and shared his thoughts on the future of public higher education in an era of uncertain prospects for political and financial support. Dr. Bartlett, 64, said that he faced a challenge that is exciting and compelling, but acknowledged that the huge university's days of unlimited expansion and little public scrutiny were over.

headline.main: Chancellor's Visit To Purchase College Tests the Future

docs.lead_paragraph: The mood is as vital as the medicine at the elegant Upper East Side clinic squeezed among the fashionable addresses of Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren and Barneys New York. Silk magnolias bloom in the marble lobby and abstract oil paintings dominate the pale rose corridors of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center's new satellite at East 60th Street and Madison Avenue.

headline.main: Vying for Patients, Hospitals Think Location, Location
